ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about why people are motivated by traveling and what people are often seeking when they travel. I also learned a lot of the problems regarding tourism and consuming other cultures, and the problematic way travel writing often frames tourism. Besides the actual content, I also learned how to critically analyze my own experiences more as well as the media I see playing out all around me, seeing ways that I can improve and not take part in these problematic experiences.
Knowledge about all the many different ways in which traveling is bad. Skills of applying theorists and theories to academic writing.
I learned about different things we should consider when we are traveling, writing about travel, and got more insight about popular tourist attractions.
I think my writing definitely grew in this course. I had to reevaluate how I write and structure convincing argumentative papers.

- How to analyze travel literature
- How to apply theoretical analysis to the world & my own experiences
- How to critically think about the impacts of travel
about travel dangers
I improved my deep reading skills, as well as gained new perspectives on topics that I had not considered before.

I learned SO much in this class. Not only did I become a better writer stylistically, but I also now know how to put together coherent arguments that logically build upon one another. This class provides you with a theoretical basis for analyzing travel and larger societal phenomena, and it truly is a toolkit that you can now take with you into future classes/life as a whole. I cannot recommend this class enough  and truly any class with TZB.
How to see the world (not just traveling) in new ways, how to apply theories to specific cases, how to tackle with difficult readings about theories, etc
This class was very conducive to self reflection and articulated a lot of my own experiences that I hadnt previously been able to unpack.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: One strength of the class is definitely the students and the positive environment that was created in the classroom. No one was overly competitive or using complicated language. It was very friendly and engaging and TZB is a great professor that takes the concerns of her students seriously. No weaknesses to note.
TZB is the biggest strength of this course. Conversations with my peers were always conducive to learning.

Strengths: Professor TZB! She explains concepts clearly and in an engaging manner. She truly cares about her students, not only academically but as people as well.
Weaknesses: Long readings. I think students would do more of the readings if there were less.
I wasn't a fan of this course at all. It was very one sided. The whole time the course was criticizing travel and NEVER once looked into the benefits of it. Not a useful course...
There was a high volume of readings weekly, which were sometimes difficult to keep up with. The professor made participating in discussion enjoyable by making space for everyone to contribute.

The strengths of this class are the absolutely phenomenal professor (TZB is the best!!), extremely interesting readings, collaborative seminar environment, and exciting writing assignments. Every student in this class looked forward to coming to class. There are genuinely no weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I highly recommend this course, the course content is very engaging, even for people interested in STEM. The class offers unique looks at tourism and introduced me to some forms of tourism that I did not even realize existed. It really makes you think critically about your own motivations for travel, your own experiences traveling, and any potential travel plans you wanted to take in the future.

I have mixed feelings about this course. I had high expectations going in because of the past reviews I read, but I definitely left with a less positive experience. I think the themes and topics we talk about are incredibly important, eye-opening, world-changing, etc. and I learned and unlearned a lot. That being said, I think it went way too far in the "you're a horrible person if you travel" direction. Not a single reading or class discussion throughout the entire semester addressed any positive impact traveling can have, and it was actually quite the contrary. People were laughing about volunteer and humanitarianism work, and although there are many flaws with that, I would have appreciated any sort of acknowledgement that there are still good people who do good work in the world. The class environment became one where you really couldn't say anything that went against the "travel is bad" narrative, and it honestly made me uncomfortable at times. From day one, tourists are literally called "ugly human beings" and the takeaway from the class is that travel is unethical and disgusting. I wish we had talked about the alternative: is it really better for everyone to stay exactly where they grew up? Also, I found the essays extremely challenging and the reading workload was quite high, so my overall experience with the class was not a pleasant one.
Yes. Some of the topics that we covered were a little uncomfortable but really necessary to understand many of the issues that we went over in the class.
YES! TZB is such a caring professor and her class was always something I looked forward to throughout the week.
Yes, changed the way I look at the world.
Yes! Incredibly eye-opening readings, professor tzb is incredibly knowledgable and helpful. Everyone should take this course!
No. If you want to sit in a classroom complaining the whole time then sure.
I would recommend this course, especially to anyone who doesn't have a background in the subject area and wants to dip their toes in the water.

TAKE THIS COURSE!! The best professor and incredible course material. The syllabus, class discussions, and writing assignments will reshape your worldview. You will look forward to this class every week!! TZB also prioritizes the mental health of students and is the most caring and understanding professor you will ever meet.

Definitely yes, as long as they are willing to engage in the discussion, listen to others and do their assignments every week. Prof TZB was the best professor Ive ever encountered at Yale and I can never thank her enough for what she did for us.
Yes! Professor tzb is an amazing teacher!
